The **Boston Celtics** are an American professional basketball team based in
[Boston, Massachusetts](/wiki/Boston "Boston"). The Celtics compete in the
[National Basketball Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association
"National Basketball Association") (NBA) as a member of the league's [Eastern
Conference](/wiki/Eastern_Conference_\(NBA\) "Eastern Conference \(NBA\)")
[Atlantic Division](/wiki/Atlantic_Division_\(NBA\) "Atlantic Division
\(NBA\)"). Founded in 1946 as one of the original eight NBA teams to survive
the league's first decade, the team is owned by [Boston Basketball Partners
LLC](/wiki/Boston_Basketball_Partners "Boston Basketball Partners"). The
Celtics play their home games at the [TD Garden](/wiki/TD_Garden "TD Garden"),
which they share with the [National Hockey
League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") (NHL)'s [Boston
Bruins](/wiki/Boston_Bruins "Boston Bruins").

The franchise are the most successful in NBA history, with 17 championships,
which accounts for 24.3 percent of all NBA championships since the league's
founding.[4] As a percentage of championships won, the Celtics are the most
successful franchise to date in the [major four traditional North American
professional sports
leagues](/wiki/Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada
"Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada").[note 1]

They have played the [Los Angeles Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los
Angeles Lakers") a [record 12 times in the NBA finals](/wiki/Celtics-
Lakers_rivalry "Celtics-Lakers rivalry"), including their most recent
appearances in [2008](/wiki/2008_NBA_Finals "2008 NBA Finals") and
[2010](/wiki/2010_NBA_Finals "2010 NBA Finals"), where the Celtics have won
nine meetings. Four Celtics players ([Bob Cousy](/wiki/Bob_Cousy "Bob Cousy"),
[Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell"), [Dave
Cowens](/wiki/Dave_Cowens "Dave Cowens") and [Larry Bird](/wiki/Larry_Bird
"Larry Bird")) have won the [NBA Most Valuable Player
Award](/wiki/NBA_Most_Valuable_Player_Award "NBA Most Valuable Player Award")
for an NBA record total of 10 MVP awards.[5] Both the nickname "Celtics" and
their mascot "Lucky the Leprechaun" are a nod to [Boston's historically large
Irish population](/wiki/History_of_Irish_Americans_in_Boston "History of Irish
Americans in Boston").[6]

After winning sixteen championships throughout the 20th century, the Celtics
rose again after struggling through the 1990s to win a championship in
[2008](/wiki/2008_NBA_Finals "2008 NBA Finals") with the help of [Kevin
Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett "Kevin Garnett"), [Paul Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce
"Paul Pierce"), and [Ray Allen](/wiki/Ray_Allen "Ray Allen") in what was known
as the new "Big Three" era, following the original "Big Three" era that
featured [Larry Bird](/wiki/Larry_Bird "Larry Bird"), [Kevin
McHale](/wiki/Kevin_McHale_\(basketball\) "Kevin McHale \(basketball\)"), and
[Robert Parish](/wiki/Robert_Parish "Robert Parish"), which combined to win
the [1981](/wiki/1980-81_NBA_season "1980-81 NBA season"),
[1984](/wiki/1983-84_NBA_season "1983-84 NBA season"), and [1986
championships](/wiki/1985-86_NBA_season "1985-86 NBA season").

Following the win in 2008, general manager [Danny Ainge](/wiki/Danny_Ainge
"Danny Ainge") began a rebuilding process with the help of head coach [Brad
Stevens](/wiki/Brad_Stevens "Brad Stevens"), who led the Celtics to a return
to the playoffs from 2015. During the [following
season](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_NBA_season "2016–17 NBA season"), the Celtics
clinched the top seed in the Eastern Conference, and eventually reached the
Conference Finals prior to losing to the [Cleveland
Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") in five games.

## Franchise
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Franchise history")]

Main article: [History of the Boston
Celtics](/wiki/History_of_the_Boston_Celtics "History of the Boston Celtics")

### 1946–1950: Early
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: 1946–1950: Early years")]

The Boston Celtics were formed on June 6, 1946, by [Boston Garden-Arena
Corporation](/wiki/Boston_Garden-Arena_Corporation "Boston Garden-Arena
Corporation") President [Walter A. Brown](/wiki/Walter_A._Brown "Walter A.
Brown") as a team in the [Basketball Association of
America](/wiki/Basketball_Association_of_America "Basketball Association of
America"), and became part of the [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") after the absorption of the [National Basketball
League](/wiki/National_Basketball_League_\(United_States\) "National
Basketball League \(United States\)") by the BAA in the fall of 1949.[7] In
1950, the Celtics signed [Chuck Cooper](/wiki/Chuck_Cooper_\(basketball\)
"Chuck Cooper \(basketball\)"), becoming the first NBA franchise to
[draft](/wiki/Draft_\(sports\) "Draft \(sports\)") a black player.[8]

### 1950–1957: Arrival of Bob Cousy and Red
Auerbach[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: 1950–1957: Arrival of Bob Cousy and Red Auerbach")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Bob_Cousy_NYWTS.jpg/200px-
Bob_Cousy_NYWTS.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bob_Cousy_NYWTS.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bob_Cousy_NYWTS.jpg "Enlarge")

[Bob Cousy](/wiki/Bob_Cousy "Bob Cousy") played 13 years for the team, winning
6 NBA titles.

The Celtics struggled during their early years, until the hiring of coach [Red
Auerbach](/wiki/Red_Auerbach "Red Auerbach").[9] In the franchise's early
days, Auerbach had no assistants, ran all the practices, did all the
scouting—both of opposing teams and college draft prospects—and scheduled all
the road trips. One of the first great players to join the Celtics was [Bob
Cousy](/wiki/Bob_Cousy "Bob Cousy"), whom Auerbach initially refused to draft
out of nearby Holy Cross because he was "too flashy".[10] Cousy eventually
became the property of the [Chicago Stags](/wiki/Chicago_Stags "Chicago
Stags"),[11] but when that franchise went bankrupt, Cousy went to the Celtics
in a dispersal draft. After the [1955–56](/wiki/1955%E2%80%9356_NBA_season
"1955–56 NBA season") season, Auerbach made a stunning trade. He sent
perennial All-Star [Ed Macauley](/wiki/Ed_Macauley "Ed Macauley") to the [St.
Louis Hawks](/wiki/St._Louis_Hawks "St. Louis Hawks") along with the draft
rights to [Cliff Hagan](/wiki/Cliff_Hagan "Cliff Hagan") in exchange for the
second overall pick in the draft.[12] After negotiating with the [Rochester
Royals](/wiki/Rochester_Royals "Rochester Royals")—a negotiation that included
a promise that the Celtics owner would send the highly sought-after [Ice
Capades](/wiki/Ice_Capades "Ice Capades") to Rochester if the Royals would let
Russell slide to #2—Auerbach used the pick to select [University of San
Francisco](/wiki/University_of_San_Francisco "University of San Francisco")
[center](/wiki/Center_\(basketball\) "Center \(basketball\)") [Bill
Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell").[13] Auerbach also acquired Holy
Cross standout, and 1957 NBA Rookie of the Year, [Tommy
Heinsohn](/wiki/Tommy_Heinsohn "Tommy Heinsohn").[14] Russell and Heinsohn
worked extraordinarily well with Cousy, and they were the players around whom
Auerbach would build the champion Celtics for more than a decade.[14]

### 1957–1969: The Bill Russell
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: 1957–1969: The Bill Russell era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Bill_russell_dribbling.jpg/200px-
Bill_russell_dribbling.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bill_russell_dribbling.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bill_russell_dribbling.jpg "Enlarge")

[Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell") played 13 years for the
team, winning 11 NBA titles.

With [Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell"), the Celtics advanced
to the [1957 NBA Finals](/wiki/1957_NBA_Finals "1957 NBA Finals") and defeated
the St. Louis Hawks in seven games, giving the Celtics the first of their
record 17 championships. Russell went on to win 11 championships, making him
the most decorated player in NBA history.[15] In 1958, the Celtics again
advanced to the [NBA Finals](/wiki/1958_NBA_Finals "1958 NBA Finals"), this
time losing to the Hawks in 6 games.[16] However, with the acquisition of
[K.C. Jones](/wiki/K.C._Jones "K.C. Jones") that year, the Celtics began a
dynasty that would last for more than a decade.[17] In 1959, the Celtics won
the NBA Championship after sweeping the [Minneapolis
Lakers](/wiki/Minneapolis_Lakers "Minneapolis Lakers"), the first of their
record eight consecutive championships.[18] During that time, the Celtics met
the Lakers in the Finals five times, starting an intense and often bitter
rivalry that has spanned generations. In 1964, the Celtics became the first
NBA team to have an all African-American starting lineup. On December 26,
1964, [Willie Naulls](/wiki/Willie_Naulls "Willie Naulls") replaced an injured
Tommy Heinsohn, joining [Tom 'Satch' Sanders](/wiki/Satch_Sanders "Satch
Sanders"), K.C. Jones, [Sam Jones](/wiki/Sam_Jones_\(basketball\) "Sam Jones
\(basketball\)"), and Bill Russell in the starting lineup. The Celtics
defeated St. Louis 97–84. Boston won its next 11 games with Naulls starting in
place of Heinsohn.[19] The Celtics of the late-1950s–1960s are widely
considered as one of the most dominant teams of all time.[20]

Auerbach retired as coach after the 1965–66 season and Russell took over as
player-coach, which was Auerbach's ploy to keep Russell interested.[21] With
his appointment, Russell also became the first African-American coach in any
U.S. pro sport. Auerbach would remain the general manager, a position he would
hold well into the 1980s. However, that year the Celtics' string of NBA titles
was broken as they lost to the [Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers
"Philadelphia 76ers") in the Eastern Conference Finals. The aging team managed
two more championships in 1968 and 1969, defeating the [Los Angeles
Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers") each time in the NBA
Finals.[22] Russell retired after the 1969 season, effectively ending a
dominant Celtics dynasty that had garnered 11 NBA titles in 13 seasons.[23]
The streak of 8 consecutive championships is the longest streak of consecutive
championships in U.S. professional sports history.[24]

### 1970–1978: Heinsohn and Cowens
duo[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: 1970–1978: Heinsohn and Cowens duo")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Tom_heinsohn_Celt.JPG/220px-
Tom_heinsohn_Celt.JPG)](/wiki/File:Tom_heinsohn_Celt.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Tom_heinsohn_Celt.JPG "Enlarge")

[Tom Heinsohn](/wiki/Tom_Heinsohn "Tom Heinsohn") coached the Boston Celtics
to the 1974 and 1976 NBA Championship.

[![Portrait photograph of white man wearing white and green
top.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Dave_Cowens_-_2005_NBA_Legends_Tour_-_1-21-05.jpg/170px-
Dave_Cowens_-_2005_NBA_Legends_Tour_-_1-21-05.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dave_Cowens_-_2005_NBA_Legends_Tour_-_1-21-05.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dave_Cowens_-_2005_NBA_Legends_Tour_-_1-21-05.jpg "Enlarge")

[Dave Cowens](/wiki/Dave_Cowens "Dave Cowens") had helped the Celtics win 2
titles during the mid-1970s.

The 1970 season was a rebuilding year, as the Celtics had their first losing
record since the [1949–50](/wiki/1949%E2%80%9350_NBA_season "1949–50 NBA
season") season. However, with the acquisition of [Dave
Cowens](/wiki/Dave_Cowens "Dave Cowens"), [Paul Silas](/wiki/Paul_Silas "Paul
Silas"), and [Jo Jo White](/wiki/Jo_Jo_White "Jo Jo White"), the Celtics soon
became dominant again.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] After losing in the Eastern Conference Finals
in 1972, the Celtics regrouped and came out determined in 1973 and posted an
excellent 68–14 regular season record. But the season ended in disappointment,
as they were upset in 7 games by the [New York Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks
"New York Knicks") in the Conference Finals. [John
Havlicek](/wiki/John_Havlicek "John Havlicek") injured his right shoulder in
game six and was forced to play game 7 shooting left handed.[25] The Celtics
returned to the playoffs the next year, defeating the [Milwaukee
Bucks](/wiki/Milwaukee_Bucks "Milwaukee Bucks") in the [NBA Finals in
1974](/wiki/1974_NBA_Finals "1974 NBA Finals") for their 12th [NBA
Championship](/wiki/NBA_Championship "NBA Championship").[26] The teams split
the first four games, and after the Celtics won Game 5 in Milwaukee they
headed back to Boston leading 3 games to 2, with a chance to claim the title
on their home court. However, the Bucks won Game 6 when [Kareem Abdul-
Jabbar](/wiki/Kareem_Abdul-Jabbar "Kareem Abdul-Jabbar") nestled in a hook
shot with 3 seconds left in the game's second overtime, and the series
returned to Milwaukee. But Cowens was the hero in Game 7, scoring 28 points,
as the Celtics brought the title back to Boston for the first time in five
years. In 1976, the team won yet another championship, defeating the [Phoenix
Suns](/wiki/Phoenix_Suns "Phoenix Suns") in 6 games. The Finals featured one
of the greatest games in the NBA's history. With the series tied at two games
apiece, the Suns trailed early in the Boston Garden, but came back to force
overtime. In double overtime, a [Gar Heard](/wiki/Gar_Heard "Gar Heard") turn-
around jumper at the top of the key sent the game to a third overtime, at
which point the Celtics prevailed.[27] [Tommy Heinsohn](/wiki/Tommy_Heinsohn
"Tommy Heinsohn") coached the team for those two championships. After the 1976
championship and a [playoff appearance in 1977](/wiki/1977_NBA_Playoffs "1977
NBA Playoffs"), Boston went into another rebuilding phase. In the [1977 NBA
draft](/wiki/1977_NBA_draft "1977 NBA draft"), the Celtics drafted a young
forward from [UNC Charlotte](/wiki/University_of_North_Carolina_at_Charlotte
"University of North Carolina at Charlotte") named [Cedric
Maxwell](/wiki/Cedric_Maxwell "Cedric Maxwell").[28] "Cornbread" Maxwell did
not contribute much in his rookie season, but he showed promise. Auerbach's
job became even tougher following the [1977–78
season](/wiki/1977%E2%80%9378_NBA_season "1977–78 NBA season") in which they
went 32–50 as [John Havlicek](/wiki/John_Havlicek "John Havlicek"), the
Celtics' all-time leading scorer, retired after 16 seasons.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### 1979–1992: The Larry Bird
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: 1979–1992: The Larry Bird era")]

The Celtics owned two of the top eight picks in the [1978 NBA
draft](/wiki/1978_NBA_draft "1978 NBA draft").[29] Since the Celtics had two
draft choices, Auerbach took a risk and selected junior [Larry
Bird](/wiki/Larry_Bird "Larry Bird") of [Indiana State](/wiki/Indiana_State
"Indiana State") with the 6th pick, knowing Bird would elect to remain in
college for his senior year. The Celtics would retain his rights for one
year—a rule that was later changed—and Auerbach believed Bird's potential
would make it worth the wait. Auerbach also felt that when the college season
ended the Celtics would have a great chance to sign Bird. Auerbach was right
and Bird signed soon after leading Indiana State to the NCAA Championship
game, where they fell to a [Michigan State
University](/wiki/Michigan_State_University "Michigan State University") team.
(The other pick was [Freeman Williams](/wiki/Freeman_Williams "Freeman
Williams"), who was traded before the 1978–79 season began.)

In 1978, ownership was changed as [Irv Levin](/wiki/Irv_Levin "Irv Levin")
traded his stake in the Celtics with [John Y. Brown,
Jr.](/wiki/John_Y._Brown,_Jr. "John Y. Brown, Jr.")'s [Buffalo
Braves](/wiki/Buffalo_Braves "Buffalo Braves"), so he could move the Braves to
California, where they became known as the [San Diego
Clippers](/wiki/San_Diego_Clippers "San Diego Clippers"). As part of the deal,
trades were made between the Braves/Clippers franchise and the Celtics
franchise which resulted in many former Braves joining the team.[30] One of
the moves that irked Auerbach was a trade Brown made with the Braves that saw
his franchise center [Bob McAdoo](/wiki/Bob_McAdoo "Bob McAdoo") join the
Celtics for three first round draft picks Auerbach had planned on using for
the future rebuilding project he was trying to undertake.[31] The dispute
nearly led to Auerbach resigning as general manager for a position with the
New York Knicks. With public support strongly behind Auerbach, Brown sold the
team to [Harry Mangurian](/wiki/Harry_Mangurian "Harry Mangurian") rather than
run the risk of having Auerbach leave the team.[32] The Celtics would struggle
through the season, going 29–53 without Bird.[33] Newcomers [Chris
Ford](/wiki/Chris_Ford "Chris Ford"), [Rick Robey](/wiki/Rick_Robey "Rick
Robey"), [Cedric Maxwell](/wiki/Cedric_Maxwell "Cedric Maxwell") and [Nate
Archibald](/wiki/Nate_Archibald "Nate Archibald") failed to reverse the team's
momentum.[34]

Bird debuted for the Celtics during the
[1979–80](/wiki/1979%E2%80%9380_NBA_season "1979–80 NBA season") season, a
year after being drafted.[35] With a new owner in place, Auerbach made a
number of moves that would bring the team back to prominence. He almost
immediately traded McAdoo,[36] a former NBA scoring champion, to the [Detroit
Pistons](/wiki/Detroit_Pistons "Detroit Pistons") for
[guard](/wiki/Guard_\(basketball\) "Guard \(basketball\)") [M. L.
Carr](/wiki/M._L._Carr "M. L. Carr"), a defensive specialist, and two first-
round picks in the [1980 NBA draft](/wiki/1980_NBA_draft "1980 NBA
draft").[32] He also picked up [point guard](/wiki/Point_guard "Point guard")
[Gerald Henderson](/wiki/Gerald_Henderson "Gerald Henderson") from the
[CBA](/wiki/Continental_Basketball_Association "Continental Basketball
Association"). Carr, Archibald, Henderson and Ford formed a highly competent
backcourt, with their unique skills blending in perfectly with the talented
frontcourt of Cowens, Maxwell and Bird, who would go on to win [NBA Rookie of
the Year](/wiki/NBA_Rookie_of_the_Year "NBA Rookie of the Year") honors.[37]
The Celtics improved by 32 games, which at the time was the best single-season
turnaround in NBA history, going 61–21 and losing to the Philadelphia 76ers in
the Eastern Conference Finals. That record was later broken by the Celtics
about 30 years later.[38]

After the season, Auerbach completed what may be the most lopsided trade in
NBA history. Auerbach had always been a fan of stockpiling draft picks, so
even after the success of the 1979–80 season, the Celtics had both the 1st and
13th picks in the [1980 NBA draft](/wiki/1980_NBA_draft "1980 NBA draft") left
over from the [M. L. Carr](/wiki/M._L._Carr "M. L. Carr") trade. Auerbach saw
an opportunity to improve the team immediately, sending the two picks to the
[Golden State Warriors](/wiki/Golden_State_Warriors "Golden State Warriors")
in exchange for [center](/wiki/Center_\(basketball\) "Center \(basketball\)")
[Robert Parish](/wiki/Robert_Parish "Robert Parish")[39] and the Warriors'
first round pick, the 3rd overall. With the draft pick, Auerbach picked
[University of Minnesota](/wiki/University_of_Minnesota "University of
Minnesota") [power forward](/wiki/Power_forward_\(basketball\) "Power forward
\(basketball\)") [Kevin McHale](/wiki/Kevin_McHale_\(basketball\) "Kevin
McHale \(basketball\)").[40] With these three future Hall of Famers on the
team, henceforth known as the first 'Big 3', the Celtics had a core in place
to again become a dominant team.

The Celtics went 62–20 under coach [Bill Fitch](/wiki/Bill_Fitch "Bill Fitch")
in [1980–81](/wiki/1980%E2%80%9381_NBA_season "1980–81 NBA season"),[41]
despite losing [center](/wiki/Center_\(basketball\) "Center \(basketball\)")
[Dave Cowens](/wiki/Dave_Cowens "Dave Cowens") to retirement late in training
camp. Once again the Celtics matched up with the 76ers in the Eastern
Conference Finals. Boston fell behind 3 games to 1 before coming back to win a
classic 7th game, 91–90. The Celtics went on to capture the 1981 NBA
Championship over the [Houston Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston
Rockets"),[42] just two years after Bird had been drafted. Maxwell was named
[NBA Finals MVP](/wiki/NBA_Finals_MVP "NBA Finals MVP").[43] [The following
year](/wiki/1981%E2%80%9382_NBA_season "1981–82 NBA season") the Celtics again
tried to come back from a 3–1 deficit against the Sixers in the rematch but
this time lost Game 7 at Boston Garden.[44] In
[1983](/wiki/1982%E2%80%9383_NBA_season "1982–83 NBA season") the Celtics were
swept in the playoffs for the first time by the Milwaukee Bucks;[45]
afterwards Fitch resigned and the team was sold to new owners led by [Don
Gaston](/wiki/Don_Gaston "Don Gaston").[46]

In [1983–84](/wiki/1983%E2%80%9384_NBA_season "1983–84 NBA season") the
Celtics, under new coach [K. C. Jones](/wiki/K._C._Jones "K. C. Jones"), would
go 62–20 and finally get back to the [NBA Finals](/wiki/1984_NBA_Finals "1984
NBA Finals") after a three-year hiatus.[47] In the finals, the Celtics came
back from a 2–1 deficit to defeat the Lakers, winning their 15th
championship.[48] Bird renewed his college rivalry with Lakers star [Magic
Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic Johnson") during this series. After the
series Auerbach officially retired as general manager but maintained the
position of team President.[49] Auerbach was succeeded by [Jan
Volk](/wiki/Jan_Volk "Jan Volk") as general manager.[49] Volk had been with
the Celtics since graduating from [Columbia Law
School](/wiki/Columbia_Law_School "Columbia Law School") in 1971 and had been
the team's [General Counsel](/wiki/General_Counsel "General Counsel") since
1976 and the team's Assistant G.M. since 1980. During the off-season, in
Volk's first major transaction since assuming the GM role, the Celtics traded
Henderson to the [Seattle SuperSonics](/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics "Seattle
SuperSonics") for their first round pick in the [1986 NBA
draft](/wiki/1986_NBA_draft "1986 NBA draft").

In 1985, the Lakers and Celtics met again, but this time the Lakers took the
championship.[50] This was the first time the Lakers had defeated the Celtics
for a championship, as well as the only time the Celtics lost a championship
at Boston Garden. During the following off-season, the Celtics acquired [Bill
Walton](/wiki/Bill_Walton "Bill Walton") from the [Los Angeles
Clippers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Clippers "Los Angeles Clippers") in exchange for
[Cedric Maxwell](/wiki/Cedric_Maxwell "Cedric Maxwell").[51] Walton was a big
star with the [Portland Trail Blazers](/wiki/Portland_Trail_Blazers "Portland
Trail Blazers"), but injuries had kept him from living up to expectations. He
was willing to come off the bench, deferring to the three big men already with
the team. Walton, considered the best passer of all NBA centers in history,
stayed healthy and was a big part of the Celtics' success in 1986.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Dennis_Johnson_Lipofsky.jpg/220px-
Dennis_Johnson_Lipofsky.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dennis_Johnson_Lipofsky.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dennis_Johnson_Lipofsky.jpg "Enlarge")

[Dennis Johnson](/wiki/Dennis_Johnson "Dennis Johnson") was another key member
of the Celtics, along with the "Big 3".

In [1985–86](/wiki/1985%E2%80%9386_NBA_season "1985–86 NBA season") the
Celtics fielded one of the best teams in NBA history. The 1986 Celtics won 67
games, going 40–1 at their home games. Bird won his third consecutive MVP
award and Walton won the [Sixth Man of the Year
Award](/wiki/Sixth_Man_of_the_Year_Award "Sixth Man of the Year Award"). They
won the franchise's 16th championship and last of the 20th century, defeating
the Houston Rockets in the [NBA Finals](/wiki/1986_NBA_Finals "1986 NBA
Finals") 4 games to 2.

Thanks to the 1984 trade of [Gerald Henderson](/wiki/Gerald_Henderson "Gerald
Henderson") and the subsequent fall of the Seattle SuperSonics, at the end of
the [1985–86](/wiki/1985%E2%80%9386_NBA_season "1985–86 NBA season") the
Celtics owned not only the best team in the NBA but also the second pick in
the [1986 NBA draft](/wiki/1986_NBA_draft "1986 NBA draft"). The Celtics
drafted [Len Bias](/wiki/Len_Bias "Len Bias") with the pick and had high hopes
for the young [University of
Maryland](/wiki/University_of_Maryland,_College_Park "University of Maryland,
College Park") star.[52] Fans believed Bias had superstar potential, and that
he would be the perfect complement to the aging, but still strong, Celtics.
The hope was his presence would ensure the franchise would remain a powerhouse
after Bird, McHale and Parish retired. Unfortunately, Bias died 48 hours after
he was drafted, after using cocaine at a party and overdosing.[53] It would be
the first in a long string of bad luck for the Celtics, one that would
continue until the next manifestation of the 'Big Three' in Boston. Despite
the loss of Bias, the Celtics remained competitive in
[1986–87](/wiki/1986%E2%80%9387_NBA_season "1986–87 NBA season"), going 59–23
and again winning the Eastern Conference Championship.[54] However, injuries
took their toll, and the Celtics ceded the NBA championship to the Lakers in
six games. It would be 21 years before they would reach the NBA Finals again.
The Celtics' reign as the Eastern Conference champions ended in 1988, after
the team lost to the Detroit Pistons in six games.[55]

After the 1987–88 season, head coach [K.C. Jones](/wiki/K.C._Jones "K.C.
Jones") retired. Jones was replaced as head coach by assistant [Jimmy
Rodgers](/wiki/Jimmy_Rodgers_\(basketball\) "Jimmy Rodgers \(basketball\)").
Rodgers faced immediate trouble in [1988–89](/wiki/1988%E2%80%9389_NBA_season
"1988–89 NBA season") when, only 6 games into the season, Larry Bird decided
to have surgery to remove bone spurs in his feet. The injury sidelined Bird
until well after the All-Star Break, although he hoped to return that year.
However, despite his best attempts to return he was unable to make it back as
the Celtics stumbled to a 42–40 record and a first round playoff defeat to the
Detroit Pistons. Bird returned in [1989–90](/wiki/1989%E2%80%9390_NBA_season
"1989–90 NBA season") and led the Celtics to a 52–30 record. In the
[playoffs](/wiki/1990_NBA_Playoffs "1990 NBA Playoffs"), after winning the
first two games of a Best of 5 series against the New York Knicks, the Celtics
collapsed, losing 3 straight, including the decisive 5th game at the [Boston
Garden](/wiki/Boston_Garden "Boston Garden"). In the wake of the embarrassing
defeat, Rodgers was fired and replaced by assistant coach and former Celtics'
player [Chris Ford](/wiki/Chris_Ford "Chris Ford").

Under Ford's leadership the Celtics improved to 56–26 in
[1990–91](/wiki/1990%E2%80%9391_NBA_season "1990–91 NBA season"), recapturing
the Atlantic Division title even though Bird missed 22 games with a variety of
injuries. The Celtics fell to the Detroit Pistons in the Eastern Conference
Semifinals. In 1992, a late season rally allowed the Celtics to catch the New
York Knicks and repeat as Atlantic Division champions. The team finished 51–31
and matched up with the [Indiana Pacers](/wiki/Indiana_Pacers "Indiana
Pacers") in the First round, this time sweeping the series. In the Eastern
Conference Semifinals the Celtics lost a grueling 7 game series to the
[Cleveland Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers"). Due to
back problems, Larry Bird played in only 45 of the 82 regular season games,
and only 4 of the 10 playoff games; during games he was frequently lying on
the floor when out of the lineup, instead of sitting on the bench. After 13
seasons with the club and winning a gold medal in the [Barcelona
Olympics](/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics "1992 Summer Olympics") with the [Dream
Team](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_basketball_team "United States
men's national basketball team"), Bird retired in 1992, primarily due to his
back injuries. Among his lasting contributions to the game was the "Bird
exception", which allows teams to exceed the salary cap to re-sign their own
free agents, at an amount up to the maximum salary.

### 1993–1998:
Rebuilding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 1993–1998: Rebuilding")]

At the time of Bird's retirement, former Celtics
[guard](/wiki/Guard_\(basketball\) "Guard \(basketball\)") [Chris
Ford](/wiki/Chris_Ford "Chris Ford") was the coach of the Celtics.[56]
26-year-old [Reggie Lewis](/wiki/Reggie_Lewis "Reggie Lewis") (out of Boston's
[Northeastern University](/wiki/Northeastern_University_\(Boston\)
"Northeastern University \(Boston\)")) was seen as Bird's successor as the
franchise player for the Celtics. Lewis, a [small forward](/wiki/Small_forward
"Small forward"), fainted during a [1993 first round
playoff](/wiki/1993_NBA_Playoffs "1993 NBA Playoffs") matchup with the
[Charlotte Hornets](/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets "Charlotte Hornets") which the
Celtics lost in four games.[57] It was later revealed that Lewis had heart
problems,[58] yet he was able to get doctors to clear him for a comeback. He
died of a heart attack while shooting baskets at Brandeis University during
the offseason.[59] The Celtics honored his memory during the following season
by retiring his number 35.[60] The original Big 3 era came to an end in 1994,
after Robert Parish signed with the Hornets[39] The year before, Kevin McHale
retired after the Celtics' playoff loss to the Hornets. The Celtics finished
the year out of the playoffs with a 32–50 mark.

In 1994, the Celtics hired former player and legendary towel-waving Celtic
cheerleader [M. L. Carr](/wiki/M._L._Carr "M. L. Carr") to be the team's new
V.P. of Basketball Operations, working alongside G.M. Jan Volk. In his first
[draft](/wiki/1994_NBA_draft "1994 NBA draft") in charge of the Celtics, he
drafted [University of North
Carolina](/wiki/University_of_North_Carolina_at_Chapel_Hill "University of
North Carolina at Chapel Hill") star [Eric Montross](/wiki/Eric_Montross "Eric
Montross") with his first round draft pick. Montross became the new heir
apparent in the paint, but failed to develop and was eventually traded.
[1994–95](/wiki/1994%E2%80%9395_NBA_season "1994–95 NBA season") was the
Celtics' final season in the [Boston Garden](/wiki/Boston_Garden "Boston
Garden"). The Celtics signed the aging [Dominique
Wilkins](/wiki/Dominique_Wilkins "Dominique Wilkins") as a free agent, and he
led the team in scoring with 17.8 PPG. Second-year player [Dino
Rađa](/wiki/Dino_Ra%C4%91a "Dino Rađa"), a power forward from
[Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"), added an interior presence to the team
that had been lacking in [1993–94](/wiki/1993%E2%80%9394_NBA_season "1993–94
NBA season"). The Celtics made the playoffs, losing to the heavily favored
[Orlando Magic](/wiki/Orlando_Magic "Orlando Magic") in 4 games. In 1995, the
Celtics moved from the Boston Garden to the Fleet Center (later TD BankNorth,
then [TD Garden](/wiki/TD_Garden "TD Garden")). Carr fired [Chris
Ford](/wiki/Chris_Ford "Chris Ford") and took the coaching reins himself.
After drafting [Providence College](/wiki/Providence_College "Providence
College") star [Eric
Williams](/w/index.php?title=Eric_Williams_\(basketball,_born_1872\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Eric Williams \(basketball, born 1872\) \(page does not exist\)"), the
Celtics struggled to a 33–49 record.

Things got worse in [1996–97](/wiki/1996%E2%80%9397_NBA_season "1996–97 NBA
season") as the Celtics lost a franchise record 67 games, setting an unwanted
[NBA record](/wiki/Imperfect_season "Imperfect season") winning only once
against other Atlantic Division teams and just fifteen victories overall
despite the emergence of 1st-round draft pick [Antoine
Walker](/wiki/Antoine_Walker "Antoine Walker"). With Carr's coaching stint
deemed a failure, he stepped aside to another job in the organization when
owner Paul Gaston convinced star college coach [Rick Pitino](/wiki/Rick_Pitino
"Rick Pitino") to join the franchise as the team's president, director of
basketball operations, and [head coach](/wiki/Head_coach "Head coach").[61]
Pitino's appointment as team president was controversial as Auerbach, who had
filled that role for more than 25 years, first heard about this change from
local media people. Unfortunately for the franchise, Pitino was not the savior
everyone expected him to be. Auerbach bore the insult of being elbowed out
with dignity, even as the team failed to improve.

The Celtics received the third and sixth draft picks in the [1997 NBA
draft](/wiki/1997_NBA_draft "1997 NBA draft"),[62] and used the picks to
select a brand new backcourt through [Chauncey Billups](/wiki/Chauncey_Billups
"Chauncey Billups") and [Ron Mercer](/wiki/Ron_Mercer "Ron Mercer"). The young
team that lost 67 games the year before was dismantled, with [David
Wesley](/wiki/David_Wesley "David Wesley"), [Dino Rađa](/wiki/Dino_Ra%C4%91a
"Dino Rađa") and [Rick Fox](/wiki/Rick_Fox "Rick Fox") being let go, and
Williams traded to the [Denver Nuggets](/wiki/Denver_Nuggets "Denver Nuggets")
for a pair of second round draft picks (Williams would return to the Celtics
in 1999 and played for four years). [Walter McCarty](/wiki/Walter_McCarty
"Walter McCarty") was also acquired in a trade with the Knicks. With a
promising start, upsetting the defending champions [Chicago
Bulls](/wiki/Chicago_Bulls "Chicago Bulls") at home on opening night,[63] and
hard play from the youngsters that led to leaderships in turnovers and steals,
the team improved its victories from 15 to 36 despite many losing
streaks.[64][65] Billups was subsequently traded to the Raptors during his
rookie year,[66] and Mercer was traded to the Nuggets during his third
season.[67]

### 1998–2013: The Paul Pierce
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: 1998–2013: The Paul Pierce era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5a/Paul_Pierce_Lipofsky.jpg)](/wiki/File:Paul_Pierce_Lipofsky.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Paul_Pierce_Lipofsky.jpg "Enlarge")

[Paul Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce "Paul Pierce"), 2008 [NBA Finals
MVP](/wiki/Bill_Russell_NBA_Finals_Most_Valuable_Player_Award "Bill Russell
NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award"), was drafted 10th overall in the [1998
NBA draft](/wiki/1998_NBA_draft "1998 NBA draft").

The following year in the [1998 NBA draft](/wiki/1998_NBA_draft "1998 NBA
draft"), the Celtics drafted [Paul Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce "Paul
Pierce"),[68] a college star who had been expected to be drafted much earlier
than the Celtics' 10th overall pick. Pierce had an immediate impact during the
lockout-shortened [1998–99 NBA season](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_NBA_season
"1998–99 NBA season"), averaging 19.5 points and being named [Rookie of The
Month](/wiki/NBA_Rookie_of_the_Month_Award "NBA Rookie of the Month Award") in
February as he led the league in steals.[69] However, the Celtics continued to
struggle as Pitino failed to achieve meaningful success. After Boston lost to
the [Toronto Raptors](/wiki/Toronto_Raptors "Toronto Raptors") on March 1,
2000, on a buzzer-beater by [Vince Carter](/wiki/Vince_Carter "Vince Carter"),
Pitino delivered the memorable "[Larry Bird](/wiki/Larry_Bird "Larry Bird") is
not walking through that door, fans" speech.[70] He resigned in January
2001.[71]

Following the resignation of Rick Pitino, the Celtics saw modest improvement
under coach [Jim O'Brien](/wiki/Jim_O%27Brien_\(basketball,_born_1952\) "Jim
O'Brien \(basketball, born 1952\)"). [Paul Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce "Paul
Pierce") matured into an NBA star and was ably complemented by Antoine Walker
and the other players acquired over the years. While the team was 12–21 when
Pitino left, O'Brien's record to finish the season was 24–24.[72] Following
the [2000–01 season](/wiki/2000%E2%80%9301_NBA_season "2000–01 NBA season")
O'Brien was given the job of head coach on a permanent basis. As a result of
numerous trades, the Celtics had three picks in the [2001 NBA
draft](/wiki/2001_NBA_draft "2001 NBA draft"). They selected [Joe
Johnson](/wiki/Joe_Johnson_\(basketball\) "Joe Johnson \(basketball\)"), [Joe
Forte](/wiki/Joseph_Forte "Joseph Forte"), and [Kedrick
Brown](/wiki/Kedrick_Brown "Kedrick Brown"). Only Johnson managed to succeed
in the NBA, becoming a perennial All-Star after leaving the Celtics.

The Celtics entered the [2001–02 season](/wiki/2001%E2%80%9302_NBA_season
"2001–02 NBA season") with low expectations. The team's success in the latter
stages of 2000–01 was largely forgotten, and critics were surprised when the
team, along with the [New Jersey Nets](/wiki/New_Jersey_Nets "New Jersey
Nets"), surged to the top of the [Atlantic
Division](/wiki/Atlantic_Division_\(NBA\) "Atlantic Division \(NBA\)") ahead
of the Philadelphia 76ers, who were fresh off a trip to the [NBA
Finals](/wiki/2001_NBA_Finals "2001 NBA Finals"). The Celtics won a hard-
fought 5-game series with the 76ers in the first round, 3–2. Pierce scored 46
points in the series-clinching blowout at the [Fleet
Center](/wiki/FleetCenter_\(Boston\) "FleetCenter \(Boston\)"). In the
Conference Semifinals, the Celtics defeated the favored Detroit Pistons 4–1.
In their first trip to the [Eastern
Conference](/wiki/Eastern_Conference_\(NBA\) "Eastern Conference \(NBA\)")
Finals since [1988](/wiki/1988_NBA_Playoffs "1988 NBA Playoffs"), the Celtics
jumped out to a 2–1 series lead over the Nets, after rallying from 21 points
down in the fourth quarter to win Game 3, but would lose the next three games
to fall 4–2.[73]

In 2003, the Celtics were sold by owner Paul Gaston to Boston Basketball
Partners L.L.C.,[74] led by [H. Irving Grousbeck](/wiki/H._Irving_Grousbeck
"H. Irving Grousbeck"), [Wycliffe Grousbeck](/wiki/Wycliffe_Grousbeck
"Wycliffe Grousbeck") and [Steve Pagliuca](/wiki/Steve_Pagliuca "Steve
Pagliuca"). The team made it back to the [playoffs](/wiki/2003_NBA_Playoffs
"2003 NBA Playoffs") but were swept by the Nets in the second round, despite
bringing Game 4 to double overtime.[75] Before their elimination, the team
hired former Celtics' guard [Danny Ainge](/wiki/Danny_Ainge "Danny Ainge") as
general manager, moving Chris Wallace to another position in the organization.
Ainge believed the team had reached its peak and promptly sent Antoine Walker
to the [Dallas Mavericks](/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks "Dallas Mavericks") (along
with [Tony Delk](/wiki/Tony_Delk "Tony Delk")).[76] In return, the Celtics
received the often-injured [Raef LaFrentz](/wiki/Raef_LaFrentz "Raef
LaFrentz"), [Chris Mills](/wiki/Chris_Mills_\(basketball\) "Chris Mills
\(basketball\)"), [Jiří Welsch](/wiki/Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Welsch "Jiří
Welsch"),[77] and a first-round pick in [2004](/wiki/2004_NBA_draft "2004 NBA
draft"). The Celtics made the [playoffs](/wiki/2004_NBA_Playoffs "2004 NBA
Playoffs"), only to be swept in the first round by the [Indiana
Pacers](/wiki/Indiana_Pacers "Indiana Pacers"), losing all 4 games by blowout
margins.[78]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Doc_Rivers.JPG/170px-
Doc_Rivers.JPG)](/wiki/File:Doc_Rivers.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Doc_Rivers.JPG "Enlarge")

Head coach [Doc Rivers](/wiki/Doc_Rivers "Doc Rivers") led the Celtics to an
NBA title in 2008.

#### 2004–2007: The "Doc" is
here[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: 2004–2007: The "Doc" is here")]

The Celtics were a young team under new coach [Doc Rivers](/wiki/Doc_Rivers
"Doc Rivers") during the 2004–05 season,[79] having drafted youngsters [Al
Jefferson](/wiki/Al_Jefferson "Al Jefferson"), [Delonte
West](/wiki/Delonte_West "Delonte West") and [Tony
Allen](/wiki/Tony_Allen_\(basketball\) "Tony Allen \(basketball\)") in the
2004 Draft. Yet they seemed to have a core of good young players, led by
Pierce and rookie [Al Jefferson](/wiki/Al_Jefferson "Al Jefferson"), to go
along with a group of able veterans. The Celtics went 45–37 and won their
first [Atlantic Division](/wiki/NBA_Atlantic_Division "NBA Atlantic Division")
title since [1991–92](/wiki/1991%E2%80%9392_NBA_season "1991–92 NBA season"),
receiving a boost from returning star Antoine Walker in mid-season. The Pacers
defeated them in the first round yet again, with the series culminating in an
embarrassing 27-point loss in Game 7 at the [Fleet
Center](/wiki/FleetCenter_\(Boston\) "FleetCenter \(Boston\)"). After the
season Walker was traded again, this time to the [Miami Heat](/wiki/Miami_Heat
"Miami Heat"). Despite Pierce's career season, in which he averaged career-
highs in points (26.8), the Celtics missed the playoffs with a 33–49 record,
owing largely to a young roster and constant roster shuffling, which saw the
likes of [Marcus Banks](/wiki/Marcus_Banks "Marcus Banks"), [Ricky
Davis](/wiki/Ricky_Davis "Ricky Davis") and [Mark Blount](/wiki/Mark_Blount
"Mark Blount") traded for underachieving former first-overall pick [Michael
Olowokandi](/wiki/Michael_Olowokandi "Michael Olowokandi") and former all-star
[Wally Szczerbiak](/wiki/Wally_Szczerbiak "Wally Szczerbiak").

The Celtics continued to rebuild in the [2006 NBA draft](/wiki/2006_NBA_draft
"2006 NBA draft"). The Celtics selected Kentucky point guard [Rajon
Rondo](/wiki/Rajon_Rondo "Rajon Rondo"), who was to become a key piece in the
team's revival. In the second round the Celtics added [Leon
Powe](/wiki/Leon_Powe "Leon Powe").[80] The [2006–07
season](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_NBA_season "2006–07 NBA season") was a gloomy
one for the franchise, starting with the death of Red Auerbach at 89. Auerbach
was one of the few remaining people who had been a part of the NBA since its
inception in 1946.[81] The Celtics went 2–22 from late December 2006 through
early February 2007 after losing Pierce to injury, the result of a stress
reaction in his left foot. At first, the Celtics received a much needed boost
from guard [Tony Allen](/wiki/Tony_Allen_\(basketball\) "Tony Allen
\(basketball\)") but he tore his [ACL](/wiki/Anterior_cruciate_ligament
"Anterior cruciate ligament") and [MCL](/wiki/Medial_collateral_ligament
"Medial collateral ligament") on a needless dunk attempt after the
whistle.[82] The Celtics compiled a record of 24–58, second-worst in the NBA,
including a franchise record [18-game losing
streak](/wiki/List_of_National_Basketball_Association_longest_losing_streaks
"List of National Basketball Association longest losing streaks").[83] At the
end of the season, the Celtics, with the second worst record in the NBA, were
at least hopeful that they could secure a high draft pick and select either
Greg Oden or Kevin Durant to help rebuild the franchise, but the Celtics fell
to fifth in the Draft Lottery.

####  2007–2012: The new 'Big Three': Pierce, Allen and
Garnett[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: 2007–2012: The new 'Big Three': Pierce, Allen and Garnett")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Your_2008_NBA_Finals_MVP_-
_The_Truth.jpg/220px-Your_2008_NBA_Finals_MVP_-
_The_Truth.jpg)](/wiki/File:Your_2008_NBA_Finals_MVP_-_The_Truth.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Your_2008_NBA_Finals_MVP_-_The_Truth.jpg "Enlarge")

The Boston Celtics celebrate after winning the 2008 NBA championship.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Celtics_champions_2008.jpg/170px-
Celtics_champions_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:Celtics_champions_2008.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Celtics_champions_2008.jpg "Enlarge")

The 17th championship banner was raised above the TD Garden rafters on October
28, 2008.

In the summer of 2007, GM [Danny Ainge](/wiki/Danny_Ainge "Danny Ainge") made
a series of moves that returned the Celtics to prominence. On draft night, he
traded the No. 5 pick [Jeff Green](/wiki/Jeff_Green_\(basketball\) "Jeff Green
\(basketball\)"), [Wally Szczerbiak](/wiki/Wally_Szczerbiak "Wally
Szczerbiak") and [Delonte West](/wiki/Delonte_West "Delonte West") to Seattle
for perennial all-star [Ray Allen](/wiki/Ray_Allen "Ray Allen") and Seattle's
second-round pick which the team used to select LSU's [Glen "Big Baby"
Davis](/wiki/Glen_Davis_\(basketball\) "Glen Davis \(basketball\)").[84] Then
the Celtics traded [Ryan Gomes](/wiki/Ryan_Gomes "Ryan Gomes"), [Gerald
Green](/wiki/Gerald_Green "Gerald Green"), Al Jefferson, [Theo
Ratliff](/wiki/Theo_Ratliff "Theo Ratliff"), and [Sebastian
Telfair](/wiki/Sebastian_Telfair "Sebastian Telfair") to Minnesota, where
Ainge's former teammate Kevin McHale was the G.M., and swapped 2009 first
round draft picks, for [MVP](/wiki/MVP "MVP") [Kevin
Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett "Kevin Garnett").[85] These moves created the
"Boston Three Party" (the nickname given to describe the combining of Allen,
Garnett, and Pierce by [Scott Van Pelt](/wiki/Scott_Van_Pelt "Scott Van Pelt")
in a "This Is Sportscenter" commercial), which would revitalize the team and
lead them back to glory.

The Celtics completed the largest single-season turnaround in
[NBA](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association")
history. The new 'Big Three' of Pierce, Allen and Garnett went 66–16 in the
regular season, a 42-game improvement. However, the team struggled initially
in the playoffs. The Atlanta Hawks took them to seven games in the first
round, as did the Cleveland Cavaliers in the conference semifinals. The
Celtics defeated the Detroit Pistons in six games of the Eastern Conference
Finals, winning two road games.[86]

In the 2008 NBA Finals, the Celtics faced MVP [Kobe Bryant](/wiki/Kobe_Bryant
"Kobe Bryant") and the Los Angeles Lakers for the 11th time, the first time
since 1987. The Celtics won Game 1 at home 98–88, fueled by strong play by
Garnett and Pierce's dramatic comeback from a second half knee injury. They
would also go on to win Game 2 108–102, despite nearly blowing a 24-point lead
in the fourth quarter. As the series shifted to Los Angeles, the Lakers
stifled Pierce and Garnett in Game 3 and won 87–81. However, the Celtics would
overcome a 24-point deficit in Game 4 to win 97–91, the largest comeback in
NBA Finals history. After again blowing a large lead, the Lakers hung on to
win Game 5 103–98, sending the series back to Boston. In Game 6, the Celtics
overpowered the Lakers, winning 131–92, clinching their 17th NBA title, and
first since 1986. It remains the most lopsided win in a championship-clinching
game; [Paul Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce "Paul Pierce") was named Finals MVP.[87]
The win in Game 6 was a sense of relief, as it was a difficult path to this
championship; in that game, these Celtics set a record for most games a team
had ever played in a postseason, with 26, surpassing the [1994 New York
Knicks](/wiki/1993%E2%80%9394_New_York_Knicks_season "1993–94 New York Knicks
season"), whom Coach [Doc Rivers](/wiki/Doc_Rivers "Doc Rivers") played for,
and the [2005 Detroit Pistons](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_Detroit_Pistons_season
"2004–05 Detroit Pistons season"), each of whom played 25, but lost their
respective finals in seven games (Knicks in [1994](/wiki/1994_NBA_Finals "1994
NBA Finals"), Pistons in [2005](/wiki/2005_NBA_Finals "2005 NBA Finals")).[88]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Taking_a_Breather.jpg/220px-
Taking_a_Breather.jpg)](/wiki/File:Taking_a_Breather.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Taking_a_Breather.jpg "Enlarge")

The Celtics during the 2008–09 season opener. L-R: [Paul
Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce "Paul Pierce"), [Kevin Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett
"Kevin Garnett"), [Eddie House](/wiki/Eddie_House "Eddie House"), [Kendrick
Perkins](/wiki/Kendrick_Perkins "Kendrick Perkins") and [Ray
Allen](/wiki/Ray_Allen "Ray Allen").

The 2008–09 Celtics started off the season at 27–2, the then-best starting
record in NBA history.[89] They also had a pair of 10+ game winning streaks
including a franchise record 19-game streak.[90] After the All Star Break,
[Kevin Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett "Kevin Garnett") was injured in a loss
against the [Utah Jazz](/wiki/Utah_Jazz "Utah Jazz"), missing the last 25
games of the season. Garnett was eventually shelved for the playoffs. The 2009
Celtics still finished with 62 victories, but their playoff run would end
against the Magic in the second round, losing in seven games after leading
3–2, the first such occurrence in team history.[91] In the prior round they
were pushed to a Game 7 against the [Chicago Bulls](/wiki/Chicago_Bulls
"Chicago Bulls"), with four of those games went to overtime, yet the Celtics'
experience was too much for the young Bulls.[92]

The following year, with the return of Garnett from injury and the additions
of [Rasheed Wallace](/wiki/Rasheed_Wallace "Rasheed Wallace") and [Marquis
Daniels](/wiki/Marquis_Daniels "Marquis Daniels"), the Celtics started the
season 23–5 and at one point had the best record in the NBA. However, Doc
Rivers decided to lessen his aging stars' minutes to keep them fresh for the
playoffs. As a result, the Celtics sputtered to an even 27–27 record the rest
of the way and finished the 2009–10 regular season with a 50–32 record, with a
better road (26–15) than home (24–17) record.[93] Despite previous predictions
the Celtics would never go deeper into the playoffs, the Celtics still managed
to make the [NBA Finals](/wiki/NBA_Finals "NBA Finals") despite their lowly
fourth seeding. They defeated the Miami Heat in five games, upset the top-
seeded Cavaliers in six games and toppled the defending Eastern champion
Magic, avenging their loss from the previous season. Rajon Rondo emerged as a
bonafide superstar during post-season play, continuing his rise to fame
beginning with his first All-Star appearance.[94] For the 12th time, the
adversary were the Lakers. After taking a 3–2 lead heading into Los Angeles
for Game 6, the Celtics appeared poised to pack in their 18th title. But
[Kendrick Perkins](/wiki/Kendrick_Perkins "Kendrick Perkins"), the team's
starting center, suffered a severe knee injury early in Game 6,[95] and the
Celtics would lose Game 6, and go on to blow a 13-point lead in Game 7. After
speculation coach [Doc Rivers](/wiki/Doc_Rivers "Doc Rivers") would resign to
spend more time with his family, he affirmed on June 30, 2010, that he would
return to the team for the 2010–11 season.

During the 2010 off season, with Perkins expected to be out until February
2011, the Celtics signed two former All-Star centers, [Shaquille
O'Neal](/wiki/Shaquille_O%27Neal "Shaquille O'Neal") and [Jermaine
O'Neal](/wiki/Jermaine_O%27Neal "Jermaine O'Neal"), along with
[Turkish](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey") center [Semih Erden](/wiki/Semih_Erden "Semih
Erden"), their [2008 second round pick](/wiki/2008_NBA_draft "2008 NBA
draft"), and the return of [Delonte West](/wiki/Delonte_West "Delonte West").
Shaquille O'Neal's presence wound up leading to Perkins departure: the Celtics
were 33–10 in games Perkins had missed during the year due to injury,[96] with
a 19–3 record with O'Neal played over 20 minutes.[97] Consequently, Perkins
was traded to the [Oklahoma City Thunder](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Thunder
"Oklahoma City Thunder") in February, when the Celtics were 41–14 and held the
Eastern Conference leaderboard despite another rash of injuries. Following the
trade, however, they proceeded to win only 15 of their final 27 games to
finish with a 56–26 record, sliding to the third seed, due to the injuries –
O'Neal played only five minutes – and difficult adjustment of new Celtics such
as [Jeff Green](/wiki/Jeff_Green_\(basketball\) "Jeff Green \(basketball\)"),
[Nenad Krstić](/wiki/Nenad_Krsti%C4%87 "Nenad Krstić") and [Carlos
Arroyo](/wiki/Carlos_Arroyo "Carlos Arroyo").[96][98] The 2010–11 season still
provided three landmarks: the Celtics became the second team to reach 3,000
victories, Paul Pierce became the third Celtic to score 20,000 points after
Larry Bird and John Havlicek, and Ray Allen broke the NBA record for most
three-pointers made in a career. The [2011 NBA
Playoffs](/wiki/2011_NBA_Playoffs "2011 NBA Playoffs") started with the
Celtics sweeping the New York Knicks 4–0 in the opening round, but in the
second round they were ousted by eventual Eastern champions Miami Heat in five
games. Shaquille O'Neal, limited to 12 minutes in two games of the second
round, retired at the end of the season.[99]

At the [2011 NBA draft](/wiki/2011_NBA_draft "2011 NBA draft"), the Celtics
acquired two [Purdue](/wiki/Purdue_Boilermakers_men%27s_basketball "Purdue
Boilermakers men's basketball") teammates, [JaJuan
Johnson](/wiki/JaJuan_Johnson "JaJuan Johnson") and [E'Twaun
Moore](/wiki/E%27Twaun_Moore "E'Twaun Moore"). During the short preseason
following the [2011 NBA lockout](/wiki/2011_NBA_lockout "2011 NBA lockout"),
the Celtics signed free agents Marquis Daniels, [Chris
Wilcox](/wiki/Chris_Wilcox "Chris Wilcox"), [Keyon
Dooling](/wiki/Keyon_Dooling "Keyon Dooling") and [Greg
Stiemsma](/wiki/Greg_Stiemsma "Greg Stiemsma"), while acquiring [Brandon
Bass](/wiki/Brandon_Bass "Brandon Bass") from the Magic for [Glen
Davis](/wiki/Glen_Davis_\(basketball\) "Glen Davis \(basketball\)") and [Von
Wafer](/wiki/Von_Wafer "Von Wafer"). They also re-signed [Jeff
Green](/wiki/Jeff_Green_\(basketball\) "Jeff Green \(basketball\)"), only to
have it voided after a physical revealed that Green was diagnosed with an
[aortic aneurysm](/wiki/Aortic_aneurysm "Aortic aneurysm"), forcing him to
miss the season. The Celtics started the season 0–3 with Paul Pierce out with
a heel injury and his replacement [Mickaël
Piétrus](/wiki/Micka%C3%ABl_Pi%C3%A9trus "Mickaël Piétrus") taking long to
debut. The struggles let to the longest losing streak in the 'Big Three' era
with five games, and by the All Star break, the Celtics were below .500 with a
15–17 record. However, they were one of the hottest teams after the break,
going 24–10 the rest of the year and winning their 5th division title in a
row. The Celtics would end up making the playoffs as the fourth seed in the
Eastern Conference in the 2012 NBA Playoffs.

In the playoffs, the Celtics faced the [Atlanta Hawks](/wiki/Atlanta_Hawks
"Atlanta Hawks") in the first round, beating them in six games led by strong
play from Pierce and Garnett. In the Conference Semifinals the Celtics faced
the Philadelphia 76ers led by [Doug Collins](/wiki/Doug_Collins_\(basketball\)
"Doug Collins \(basketball\)") and a young group of promising players that
would push the Celtics into a full-seven game series. Following a Game 7 85–75
win the Celtics faced the Miami Heat in the Eastern Conference Finals, who had
defeated them in the playoffs the previous year. After losing the first two
games in Miami, Boston fought back and won the next three games. With the
possibility of closing the series at home, the C suffered a blowout loss at
the TD Garden of 98–79, taking the series back to Miami for Game 7, where the
Celtics built an early lead but eventually lost 101–88; Miami would go on to
defeat the Oklahoma City Thunder in the Finals.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Rajon_Rondo_Media_Day.jpg/220px-
Rajon_Rondo_Media_Day.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rajon_Rondo_Media_Day.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rajon_Rondo_Media_Day.jpg "Enlarge")

[Rajon Rondo](/wiki/Rajon_Rondo "Rajon Rondo") became the Celtics' leader
after the 'Big Three' left.

The 2012 offseason started with the Celtics having only six players under
contract. While Kevin Garnett renewed, Ray Allen chose to sign with the Miami
Heat for less money, bringing the five-year 'Big Three' era to a somewhat
acrimonious end. The Celtics also signed free agents [Jason
Terry](/wiki/Jason_Terry "Jason Terry"), [Jason Collins](/wiki/Jason_Collins
"Jason Collins"), [Darko Miličić](/wiki/Darko_Mili%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Darko
Miličić") and [Leandro Barbosa](/wiki/Leandro_Barbosa "Leandro Barbosa");
acquired [Courtney Lee](/wiki/Courtney_Lee "Courtney Lee") in a three-team
sign and trade – where Johnson, Moore, Sean Williams and a future second round
pick were sent to the Houston Rockets and the Portland Trail Blazers got Sasha
Pavlovic; drafted three players, [Jared Sullinger](/wiki/Jared_Sullinger
"Jared Sullinger"), [Fab Melo](/wiki/Fab_Melo "Fab Melo") and [Kris
Joseph](/wiki/Kris_Joseph "Kris Joseph"); and renewed with [Brandon
Bass](/wiki/Brandon_Bass "Brandon Bass") along with [Chris
Wilcox](/wiki/Chris_Wilcox "Chris Wilcox") and [Jeff
Green](/wiki/Jeff_Green_\(basketball\) "Jeff Green \(basketball\)"), who both
were returning to play after sustaining season-ending heart ailments.

Despite losing Rondo and Sullinger to injury, the Celtics compiled a seven-
game winning streak, including victories over the Heat in double overtime and
the Nuggets in triple overtime. The winning streak was snapped on February 12
when Leandro Barbosa suffered a season-ending torn ACL. To compensate, the
Celtics signed swingman [Terrence Williams](/wiki/Terrence_Williams "Terrence
Williams"), forwards [D. J. White](/wiki/D._J._White "D. J. White") and
[Shavlik Randolph](/wiki/Shavlik_Randolph "Shavlik Randolph"), and traded
Barbosa and Collins to the Washington Wizards in exchange for guard Jordan
Crawford.[100][101] The Celtics finished the season with 41 wins, but played
only 81 games after a home game against the Indiana Pacers on April 16 was
cancelled following the [Boston Marathon
bombings](/wiki/Boston_Marathon_bombings "Boston Marathon bombings"); the game
was not made up with both teams already assured of their playoff
positions.[102] The 41 wins were the lowest totals the Celtics achieved as a
playoff-bound team since 2004. The Celtics trailed 3–0 to the New York Knicks
in the first round of the [2013 NBA Playoffs](/wiki/2013_NBA_Playoffs "2013
NBA Playoffs"), before losing the series in six games. In Game 6, the Celtics
nearly completed a come back when they went on a 20–0 run to cut the lead to
4, but that was the closest they got as the New York Knicks would take over to
win.[103]

During the offseason, head coach [Doc Rivers](/wiki/Doc_Rivers "Doc Rivers")
was allowed out of his contract and left to coach the Los Angeles Clippers,
giving the Celtics a 2015 unprotected first round pick as compensation. A few
days later, Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett (after waiving his no-trade clause),
along with [Jason Terry](/wiki/Jason_Terry "Jason Terry") and [D. J.
White](/wiki/D._J._White "D. J. White"), were traded to the [Brooklyn
Nets](/wiki/Brooklyn_Nets "Brooklyn Nets") for [Keith
Bogans](/wiki/Keith_Bogans "Keith Bogans"), [MarShon
Brooks](/wiki/MarShon_Brooks "MarShon Brooks"), [Kris
Humphries](/wiki/Kris_Humphries "Kris Humphries"), [Kris
Joseph](/wiki/Kris_Joseph "Kris Joseph"), [Gerald
Wallace](/wiki/Gerald_Wallace "Gerald Wallace"), and three future first-round
draft picks (2014, 2016, 2018), with the right to swap 2017 first-round picks
with Brooklyn.[104] The deal was later approved by the league on July 12,
2013, effectively ending the 'Big 3' era and marking the start of a youth
movement for the team.[105]

### 2013–present: Brad Stevens
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: 2013–present: Brad Stevens era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Brad_Stevens_on_Butler_sideline.jpg/170px-
Brad_Stevens_on_Butler_sideline.jpg)](/wiki/File:Brad_Stevens_on_Butler_sideline.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Brad_Stevens_on_Butler_sideline.jpg "Enlarge")

[Brad Stevens](/wiki/Brad_Stevens "Brad Stevens") is the Celtics' current head
coach.

On July 3, 2013, the Celtics announced that [Brad Stevens](/wiki/Brad_Stevens
"Brad Stevens"), the head coach of [Butler
University](/wiki/Butler_Bulldogs_men%27s_basketball "Butler Bulldogs men's
basketball"), would replace Doc Rivers as head coach.[106] Halfway through the
season, in January, Rajon Rondo made his return and was named the 15th Team
Captain in team history, and the team furthered the youth movement by
acquiring two draft picks in a three team trade that sent Jordan Crawford and
MarShon Brooks to the Golden State Warriors while the Celtics received the
Heat center [Joel Anthony](/wiki/Joel_Anthony "Joel Anthony"). The 2013–14
season marked the Celtics' first missed playoffs since the 'Big Three'.[107]

The next off-season, the Celtics drafted [Marcus Smart](/wiki/Marcus_Smart
"Marcus Smart") with the 6th overall pick and [James
Young](/wiki/James_Young_\(basketball\) "James Young \(basketball\)") with the
17th overall pick in the [2014 NBA draft](/wiki/2014_NBA_draft "2014 NBA
draft"),[108] and signed [Evan Turner](/wiki/Evan_Turner "Evan Turner"). The
2014–15 season had several roster moves, the most prominent being Rondo and
rookie [Dwight Powell](/wiki/Dwight_Powell "Dwight Powell") traded to the
Dallas Mavericks for center [Brandan Wright](/wiki/Brandan_Wright "Brandan
Wright"), forward [Jae Crowder](/wiki/Jae_Crowder "Jae Crowder"), veteran
point guard [Jameer Nelson](/wiki/Jameer_Nelson "Jameer Nelson"), and future
picks.[109] A total of 22 players spent time with the Celtics,[110] leading
scorer and rebounder Sullinger suffered a season-ending left metatarsal stress
fracture,[111] and the team was only tenth in the East with 28 games
remaining.[112] However, midseason acquisition [Isaiah
Thomas](/wiki/Isaiah_Thomas_\(basketball\) "Isaiah Thomas \(basketball\)")
helped the team win 22 of their last 34 games, finishing the season with a
40–42 record, enough for the seventh seed in the [Eastern Conference
Playoffs](/wiki/2015_NBA_Playoffs "2015 NBA Playoffs").[113] The Celtics were
swept by the second seeded Cleveland Cavaliers in the first round.

In the [2015 NBA draft](/wiki/2015_NBA_draft "2015 NBA draft") Boston selected
[Terry Rozier](/wiki/Terry_Rozier "Terry Rozier"), [R.J.
Hunter](/wiki/R.J._Hunter "R.J. Hunter"), [Jordan Mickey](/wiki/Jordan_Mickey
"Jordan Mickey"), and [Marcus
Thornton](/wiki/Marcus_Thornton_\(basketball,_born_1993\) "Marcus Thornton
\(basketball, born 1993\)") with the 16th, 28th, 33rd, and 45th selections
respectively. During the off-season, the Celtics signed forward [Amir
Johnson](/wiki/Amir_Johnson "Amir Johnson") and traded [Gerald
Wallace](/wiki/Gerald_Wallace "Gerald Wallace") and [Chris
Babb](/wiki/Chris_Babb "Chris Babb") in exchange for Warriors forward David
Lee. The Celtics finished the 2015–16 NBA season with a 48–34 record, earning
the fifth seed in the Eastern Conference. They played the fourth seed Atlanta
Hawks in the first round of the playoffs. After leading by 3 points in the
fourth quarter of Game 1, guard Avery Bradley went down with a hamstring
injury, making him sit out for the rest of the series. The Celtics lost the
series 4–2 to the Hawks, ending their season.

On July 8, 2016, the Celtics signed 4-time All-Star [Al
Horford](/wiki/Al_Horford "Al Horford").[114] The Celtics finished the
[2016–17 season](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_NBA_season "2016–17 NBA season") with a
53–29 record and clinched the top seed in the Eastern Conference.[115] After a
hip injury ended Thomas' impressive playoff run in game 2 of the Eastern
Conference Finals,[116] the Celtics eventually lost to the Cavaliers in five
games.

#### 2017 roster overhaul: Irving and
Hayward[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: 2017 roster overhaul: Irving and Hayward")]

For the [2017 NBA draft](/wiki/2017_NBA_draft "2017 NBA draft"), the Celtics
won the draft lottery, earning them the first pick.[note 2] They were
projected to select freshman guard [Markelle Fultz](/wiki/Markelle_Fultz
"Markelle Fultz"), but the pick was subsequently traded to the [Philadelphia
76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers") in exchange for the
third pick in the 2017 draft and future picks.[117] The 76ers would go on to
draft Fultz, while the Celtics used the third pick to select freshman forward
[Jayson Tatum](/wiki/Jayson_Tatum "Jayson Tatum"). [Semi
Ojeleye](/wiki/Semi_Ojeleye "Semi Ojeleye"), [Kadeem Allen](/wiki/Kadeem_Allen
"Kadeem Allen"), and [Jabari Bird](/wiki/Jabari_Bird "Jabari Bird") were
selected with the 37th, 53rd, and 56th selections, respectively, in the second
round.[118] At the start of the off-season, the team signed Tatum and [Ante
Žižić](/wiki/Ante_%C5%BDi%C5%BEi%C4%87 "Ante Žižić"),[119] among others, with
the biggest acquisition being the signing of [Gordon
Hayward](/wiki/Gordon_Hayward "Gordon Hayward").[120] On August 22, 2017, the
Celtics agreed to a deal that sent [Isaiah
Thomas](/wiki/Isaiah_Thomas_\(basketball\) "Isaiah Thomas \(basketball\)"),
[Jae Crowder](/wiki/Jae_Crowder "Jae Crowder"), Žižić, and the Brooklyn Nets'
2018 first-round draft pick to the [Cleveland
Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") in exchange for
[Kyrie Irving](/wiki/Kyrie_Irving "Kyrie Irving").[121] An additional draft
pick (Celtics' 2020 second-round) was later added to the package from the
Celtics to the Cavaliers after doctors revealed that Thomas's injury was more
significant than initially anticipated.[122]

By the end of the off-season, only 4 Celtics' players remained from the
[2016–17 squad](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Boston_Celtics_season "2016–17 Boston
Celtics season"),[123] with [Marcus Smart](/wiki/Marcus_Smart "Marcus Smart")
being the longest tenured Celtic from the [2014 NBA
draft](/wiki/2014_NBA_draft "2014 NBA draft").

## Rivalries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Rivalries")]

### Atlanta
Hawks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Atlanta Hawks")]

The **Celtics-[Hawks](/wiki/Atlanta_Hawks "Atlanta Hawks") rivalry** is a
[rivalry](/wiki/List_of_sports_rivalries "List of sports rivalries") in the
[Eastern Conference](/wiki/Eastern_Conference_\(NBA\) "Eastern Conference
\(NBA\)") of the [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") that has lasted for over five decades, although the two teams
have played each other since the 1949–50 season, when the then-**[Tri-
Cities](/wiki/Quad_Cities "Quad Cities") Blackhawks** joined the NBA as part
of the [National Basketball
League](/wiki/National_Basketball_League_\(United_States\) "National
Basketball League \(United States\)") and the [Basketball Association of
America](/wiki/Basketball_Association_of_America "Basketball Association of
America") merger. However, the Blackhawks could not field a truly competitive
team until they moved to [St. Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis") as the **St.
Louis Hawks** after a four-year stopover at [Milwaukee](/wiki/Milwaukee
"Milwaukee"). The two teams have faced each other eleven times in the NBA
Playoffs, four times in the [NBA Finals](/wiki/NBA_Finals "NBA Finals"), with
the Celtics winning ten of twelve series against the Hawks, including three
out of four NBA Finals.[124] While the Hawks have only defeated the Celtics
twice out of eleven series in the NBA Playoffs, they still often managed to
make their series with the Celtics memorable. The rivalry intensified in 2016
with Hawks All-Star Center [Al Horford](/wiki/Al_Horford "Al Horford")
spurning the team and joining the Celtics.

### New York
Knicks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: New York Knicks")]

Main article: [Celtics–Knicks rivalry](/wiki/Celtics%E2%80%93Knicks_rivalry
"Celtics–Knicks rivalry")

The rivalry between the Celtics and the [New York
Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks") stems from the location of
the teams, both of which are in the NBA's Atlantic division. It is one of many
rivalries between Boston and New York teams. Boston and New York are also the
only two original NBA franchises that have remained in the same city for the
duration of their existence. The teams have played 512 games against each
other during the regular season, with the Celtics winning 276 times. The two
teams have also faced each other 61 times during the playoffs, with the
Celtics winning 34 times.[125]

### Philadelphia
76ers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Philadelphia 76ers")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Wilt_Chamberlain_Bill_Russell_2.jpg/170px-
Wilt_Chamberlain_Bill_Russell_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wilt_Chamberlain_Bill_Russell_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wilt_Chamberlain_Bill_Russell_2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Wilt Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt Chamberlain") of the
Philadelphia 76ers being defended against by [Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell
"Bill Russell") of the Boston Celtics.

Main article: [76ers–Celtics rivalry](/wiki/76ers%E2%80%93Celtics_rivalry
"76ers–Celtics rivalry")

The Celtics and the [Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers
"Philadelphia 76ers") are the two teams who have the most meetings in the [NBA
Playoffs](/wiki/NBA_Playoffs "NBA Playoffs"), playing each other in 19 series,
of which the Celtics have won 12.[126] The 76ers are considered as the
Celtics' biggest rival in the Eastern Conference. The rivalry reached its peak
when players Bill Russell and [Wilt Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt
Chamberlain") of the 76ers played each other from 1965 to 1968. Their play
would result in the Celtics not winning every NBA Finals series in the 1960s
when the Sixers won in 1967.[127] During the early 1980s, the teams constantly
fought for conference championships with Larry Bird leading the Celtics and
[Julius Erving](/wiki/Julius_Erving "Julius Erving") leading the
76ers.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

### Detroit
Pistons[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Detroit Pistons")]

Main article: [Celtics–Pistons rivalry](/wiki/Celtics%E2%80%93Pistons_rivalry
"Celtics–Pistons rivalry")

The rivalry between the Celtics and the [Detroit
Pistons](/wiki/Detroit_Pistons "Detroit Pistons") peaked in the 1980s,
featuring players such as Larry Bird, Kevin McHale, Robert Parish, [Isiah
Thomas](/wiki/Isiah_Thomas "Isiah Thomas"), [Bill
Laimbeer](/wiki/Bill_Laimbeer "Bill Laimbeer"), [Dennis
Rodman](/wiki/Dennis_Rodman "Dennis Rodman"), and [Joe
Dumars](/wiki/Joe_Dumars "Joe Dumars"). These teams met in the [NBA
Playoffs](/wiki/NBA_Playoffs "NBA Playoffs") five times in 7 seasons from 1985
to 1991, with the Celtics winning in 1985 and 1987, and the Pistons coming out
on top en route to back-to-back Finals appearances in
[1988](/wiki/1988_NBA_Finals "1988 NBA Finals") and their championship seasons
of [1989](/wiki/1989_NBA_Finals "1989 NBA Finals") and
[1990](/wiki/1990_NBA_Finals "1990 NBA Finals"). Led by [Paul
Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce "Paul Pierce"), [Kevin Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett
"Kevin Garnett") and [Ray Allen](/wiki/Ray_Allen "Ray Allen") in the 2008
[Eastern Conference Finals](/wiki/NBA_Conference_Finals "NBA Conference
Finals") the Celtics defeated the Pistons in 6 games to advance to the NBA
Finals where they went on to beat the Lakers also in 6 games.[128]

### Los Angeles
Lakers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Los Angeles Lakers")]

Main article: [Celtics–Lakers rivalry](/wiki/Celtics%E2%80%93Lakers_rivalry
"Celtics–Lakers rivalry")

The rivalry between the Boston Celtics and [Los Angeles
Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers") involves the two most
storied franchises in NBA history. It has been called the NBA's best
rivalry.[129] The two teams have met a record twelve times in the [NBA
Finals](/wiki/NBA_Finals "NBA Finals"), starting with their first Finals
meeting in [1959](/wiki/1959_NBA_Finals "1959 NBA Finals"). They would go on
to dominate the league in the 1960s and the 1980s, facing each other six times
in the 1960s, three times in the 1980s, in 2008, and in 2010.

The rivalry had been less intense since the retirements of [Magic
Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic Johnson") and Larry Bird in the early
1990s, but in 2008 it was renewed as the Celtics and Lakers met in the Finals
for the first time since 1987, with the Celtics winning the series in six
games. They faced off once again in the [2010 NBA
Finals](/wiki/2010_NBA_Finals "2010 NBA Finals") which the Lakers won in seven
games. The two teams have won the two highest numbers of championships, the
Celtics 17, the Lakers 16; together, the 33 championships account for almost
half of the [70 championships](/wiki/List_of_NBA_champions "List of NBA
champions") in NBA history.

### Brooklyn
Nets[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Brooklyn Nets")]

The Boston Celtics were once rivals of the [New Jersey
Nets](/wiki/Brooklyn_Nets "Brooklyn Nets") during the early 2000s due to their
respective locations and their burgeoning stars. The Nets were led by [Jason
Kidd](/wiki/Jason_Kidd "Jason Kidd") and [Kenyon Martin](/wiki/Kenyon_Martin
"Kenyon Martin"), while the Celtics were experiencing newfound success behind
Paul Pierce and Antoine Walker. The rivalry began to heat up in the 2002
Eastern Conference Finals, which was preceded by trash talking from the
Celtics[130] who claimed Martin was a "fake" tough guy. Things progressed as
the series started, and on-court tensions seemed to spill into the stands.
Celtics' fans berated Kidd and his family with chants of "Wife Beater!"[131]
in response to Kidd's 2001 domestic abuse charge. When asked about the fan
barbs being traded, [Kenyon Martin](/wiki/Kenyon_Martin "Kenyon Martin")
stated, "Our fans hate them, their fans hate us." [Bill
Walton](/wiki/Bill_Walton "Bill Walton") said at the time that Nets-Celtics
was the "beginning of the next great NBA rivalry" during the Eastern
Conference Finals in 2002 with the Nets advancing to the NBA Finals, though
New Jersey would go on to sweep Boston in the 2003 playoffs. In 2012, the year
the Nets returned to New York in the borough of Brooklyn, there were
indications that the rivalry might be rekindled when an altercation occurred
on the court on November 28, resulting in the ejection of [Rajon
Rondo](/wiki/Rajon_Rondo "Rajon Rondo"), Gerald Wallace, and Kris Humphries.
Rondo was suspended for two games in the aftermath, while Wallace and [Kevin
Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett "Kevin Garnett") were fined.[132] The story was
revisited on December 25, when Wallace grabbed Garnett's shorts and the two
had to be broken up by referees and players alike. However, the rivalry
between the Nets and the Celtics appeared significantly cooled off by the June
2013 blockbuster trade that dealt Celtics stars Garnett and [Paul
Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce "Paul Pierce") to the Nets in exchange for Wallace,
Humphries, and others. This move was billed as a merger of the two [Atlantic
Division](/wiki/Atlantic_Division_\(NBA\) "Atlantic Division \(NBA\)")
teams.[133] Celtics announcer [Sean Grande](/wiki/Sean_Grande "Sean Grande")
said "It's almost as if you found a great home for these guys. You couldn't
have found a better place. These guys will be in the New York market, they'll
be on a competitive team, they'll stay on national TV. It's funny, because the
enemy of my enemy is my friend. So with Celtics fans feeling the way they do
about the Heat, feeling the way they do about the Knicks, the Nets are going
to become almost the second [Boston] team now."[134]

## Records, retired numbers and
awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Records, retired numbers and awards")]

Main article: [List of Boston Celtics accomplishments and
records](/wiki/List_of_Boston_Celtics_accomplishments_and_records "List of
Boston Celtics accomplishments and records")

The Celtics have a NBA record 17 Championships including 8 in a row, and 11
championships in 13 years. They also have 52 playoff appearances. The
[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Naismith_Memorial_Basketball_Hall_of_Fame "Naismith Memorial
Basketball Hall of Fame") have 40 enshrined players who played for the
Celtics,[135] and the franchise is the one with the most [retired
numbers](/wiki/Retired_number "Retired number") in all American sports, with
21.[136]

## Coaches[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Coaches")]

### Head
coaches[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Boston_Celtics&action=edit&section=30 "Edit
section: Head coaches")]

Main article: [List of Boston Celtics head
coaches](/wiki/List_of_Boston_Celtics_head_coaches "List of Boston Celtics
head coaches")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b5/Auerbach_Lipofsky.jpg)](/wiki/File:Auerbach_Lipofsky.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Auerbach_Lipofsky.jpg "Enlarge")

[Red Auerbach](/wiki/Red_Auerbach "Red Auerbach") coached the Boston Celtics
to 9 NBA titles, with eight straight titles between 1959 and 1966.

There have been 17 head coaches in Celtics' history. [Red
Auerbach](/wiki/Red_Auerbach "Red Auerbach") is the most successful
franchise's head coach having won 9 NBA championships with the team. Celtics'
legend [Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell") took coaching duties
from Auerbach and led them to 2 NBA championships while playing and coaching
at the same time. The other two coaches that won 2 NBA titles with the team
are [Tom Heinsohn](/wiki/Tom_Heinsohn "Tom Heinsohn") and [K. C.
Jones](/wiki/K._C._Jones "K. C. Jones"). Both [Bill Fitch](/wiki/Bill_Fitch
"Bill Fitch") and [Doc Rivers](/wiki/Doc_Rivers "Doc Rivers") led the Celtics
to 1 NBA championship the latter being the most recent coach to do so. [Brad
Stevens](/wiki/Brad_Stevens "Brad Stevens") is the current head coach for the
team.[106]
